text: America should never be dependent on the Chinese Communist Party for the critical minerals that power our phones, vehicles, weapons systems, and power grid, which is why I cosponsored the Securing America’s Mineral Supply Act. This bill makes permanent President Trump’s executive orders to strengthen American mineral production and reduce reliance on foreign adversaries, helping safeguard our economy, protect our military readiness, and put American workers first.

I just voted to avert a government shutdown and keep essential government services fully funded, including those for our troops, seniors, working families, and border enforcement. With the bill passed, it now heads to the Senate this weekend. After nearly every House Democrat voted against funding the government, will Chuck Schumer decide to shut it all down just to spite President Trump?

Today on POW/MIA Recognition Day, we honor the brave Americans who were taken prisoner in defense of our nation and those who never returned home. Their sacrifice, and the pain carried by their families, must never be forgotten. As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I will continue working to bring every possible hero home and to honor the sacrifice of those who never made it back.
Big win from the Trump administration for our veterans!

This week, I voted on a series of bills to make Washington, D.C., safer for residents and law enforcement. These bills strengthen criminal sentencing, allow police to take necessary action against dangerous suspects, and ensure serious juvenile offenders are held accountable. It’s vital for our nation’s capital to be safe, and every American deserves to live in a secure community. These measures build on President Trump’s successful efforts to restore law and order, and I’m proud to help get them passed in the House.

I met with AmericanHort, which represents the nursery and greenhouse industry, to talk about priorities for the upcoming Farm Bill. As a member of the House Agriculture Committee, I’ll keep working to make sure the bill supports growers, strengthens our supply chains, and gives Southern Illinois agriculture the tools it needs to thrive.

Happy 78th birthday to the United States Air Force. Here in Southern Illinois, we’re especially proud of Scott Air Force Base, which plays a vital role in our national defense and is one of our region’s largest employers. I’m grateful to the men and women of the Air Force and their families for their service and sacrifice to keep America safe.

Great news from the Department of Veterans Affairs this week: the backlog of veterans waiting for benefits is down 45%. As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’ll keep working to build on this progress and ensure every veteran gets the care and support they have earned without delay.

Today is Constitution Day, a reminder of the sacred document that has kept our Republic strong for more than two centuries. The Constitution was written to protect the rights of the people and limit the power of government. When I took the oath of office, I swore to uphold it, and I’ve made it my focus to ensure every decision I make in Congress follows the Constitution. I will always fight to defend this foundation of our freedom for future generations.

I met with members of the Illinois Manufacturers’ Association today, including representatives from Boeing’s Mascoutah facility and Carbondale’s Intertape Polymer Group. We had a productive conversation about keeping supply chains strong and taxes low for working families and job creators. I will continue fighting for policies that allow them to grow and create good-paying jobs in Southern Illinois.

Earlier today, I had the privilege of greeting another group of veterans as they arrived in Washington, D.C. on the Southern Illinois Honor Flight, a program that brings these heroes to the nation’s capital free of charge to visit their war memorials. Greeting and thanking a new group of veterans is always an incredibly moving highlight of my job.

The National Institutes of Health will not renew federal grants for research using aborted fetal tissue. I have long fought to end the use of taxpayer dollars for this kind of research. Thank you President Trump for righting this wrong and reestablishing that America is a nation that values life.

Tonight I joined my colleagues in Congress at a prayer vigil for Charlie Kirk. Together, we mourn the loss of a life taken far too soon and lift up his family, loved ones, and all those impacted by his horrific and hateful assassination. May God grant them comfort and peace in this difficult time.

Today I managed debate on the House floor as we considered 14 bipartisan veterans bills that will help boost health care access for those who served, improve the VA disability claims process, and modernize the transition to civilian life for our active-duty men and women. As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, it will continue to be my priority to make sure our veterans receive the care and benefits they have earned.

Heard word this afternoon of the passing of former Illinois governor Jim Edgar. Jim was the first governor I served with in Springfield, and I will forever value his friendship and steadfast service to our state. Tracy’s and my prayers go out to Brenda and their family and friends during this difficult time.

I had the pleasure of meeting with advocates from Challenge Unlimited and SourceAmerica, including SourceAmerica representative Ryan Blackman, Craig Lappe from Aviston, Zachary Smith from Fairview Heights, and Tabitha Yates from Wood River. They are part of the AbilityOne Program, which provides meaningful employment opportunities for people with disabilities, including at Scott Air Force Base. It was inspiring to hear firsthand how this program made a real difference in their lives.

Today kicks off National Truck Driver Appreciation Week, a recognition I pushed for earlier this year in Congress with a resolution honoring the hard work of professional truck drivers. More than 3.5 million truckers deliver nearly 70 percent of our nation’s freight, often spending long hours on the road, facing storms and emergencies, while weeks away from home to keep our economy and supply chain moving. Having worked in my family’s trucking business in Murphysboro, I know the dedication it takes, and I’m proud to honor these essential Americans this week.

I was honored to receive the Fueling Growth Award from Growth Energy for supporting Southern Illinois agriculture and the ethanol industry. Promoting biofuels is vital for giving our farmers more opportunities and lowering costs for consumers. https://t.co/qFVG0gtKmk

For too long, weak enforcement under the Biden-Harris Administration allowed dangerous individuals to break our laws and threaten American communities. That’s why I proudly voted for the Stop Illegal Entry Act to strengthen our ability to hold criminal aliens accountable for illegally entering and reentering the United States.  This legislation ensures that those who repeatedly violate our immigration laws face tougher consequences, supports federal officials in prosecuting offenders, and prioritizes law and order to keep our communities safe.

I sat down with the Illinois Automobile Dealers Association to discuss challenges and opportunities facing the automotive industry. I also highlighted how I recently supported the largest working families tax cut in history, which provides a significant deduction for auto loan interest and helps make buying a car more affordable for families. I appreciated hearing their perspectives and will continue working to support a strong and thriving auto industry in Southern Illinois.

I voted this week for a Defense authorization bill that strengthens our military, provides a well-deserved pay raise to our troops, and helps military families. The bill includes the BOOTS Act, which I cosponsored to make sure combat boots are made in the U.S. at facilities like Belleville Boot Company. Providing our troops the best equipment, vehicles, and weapons is essential to keeping them safe and combat ready.

Charlie Kirk was a native son of Illinois whose faith, love of family, and commitment to thoughtfully engaging young people in the political process will leave a lasting mark. To honor him, today I joined fellow Illinois Republicans Mary Miller and Darin LaHood in introducing a House resolution honoring Charlie’s life and legacy. My prayers go out to his wife, Erika, their two young children, and all who were impacted by this horrific attack.

Today we remember and honor the lives lost on September 11, 2001, and the heroes who ran toward danger to save others. We also recognize the sacrifices of first responders, military members, and everyday Americans who stood united in the face of terror. On this day, we reaffirm our commitment to never forget and to always defend our nation, our values, and each other.

The murder of Charlie Kirk reflects just how far our nation has spiraled from the days of political discourse to the depths of political violence. No American should fear for their life simply for sharing their point-of-view. Rest in peace, Charlie Kirk.

Tracy and I are shocked and saddened by the horrific attack on conservative leader @charliekirk11 at Utah Valley University today. Our prayers are with him and his family as we await confirmation of his condition.

I was proud to receive this week the Legislator of the Year award from Vietnam Veterans of America for my work advocating for our Vietnam-era veteran community. As a Marine and Chairman of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs, I believe there is no obligation more sacred than ensuring our veterans get the care and benefits they earned, and I’ll keep doing all I can to make sure no veteran is left behind.

The Justice Department is right to push back on Illinois’ new law that gives in-state tuition and scholarships to those here illegally while leaving law-abiding American citizens behind. Federal law clearly says that states cannot hand out education benefits based on residency to illegal immigrants unless those same benefits are available to every U.S. citizen, no matter where they live. I fully support Attorney General Bondi’s action to stop this violation of federal law, and I’ll keep working with President Trump to make sure we put our citizens first.

I was proud to help President Trump deliver the largest middle-class tax cut in history, providing Illinois families a $13,500 increase in yearly take-home pay. Not only will you take home more of what you earn, but you’ll see no more taxes on tips and overtime, unprecedented tax relief for seniors’ Social Security, and an expanded Child Tax Credit to help parents provide for their children. While every single Democrat voted to raise your taxes, I was happy to fight for pro-worker, pro-family tax relief that strengthens our economy.

Congratulations to Marion’s Market Street Music Conservatory Adult Choir on being selected to perform at the White House this Christmas season. This is an incredible honor and a wonderful opportunity to showcase the talent and spirit of Southern Illinois on the national stage!

I had the chance to meet with Charles and Tamra Peck, as well as Carly and Lucas Jones, from Karnak, who serve their community as firefighters. As one of the only professional firefighters in Congress, I never miss an opportunity to visit with those who keep us safe. I will continue working to ensure our first responders have the resources and support they need to do their jobs safely. Glad my office was able to help facilitate a tour of the U.S. Capitol during their visit to Washington! If you’re interested in scheduling a tour as well, visit my website at https://t.co/C1IQ1T5lve and we’ll see what we can do to help.

This week I voted for the Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act to strengthen our national security and ensure America’s energy independence. This bill makes critical investments in our nuclear capabilities, supports new energy technologies, and puts our vast natural resources to work for the American people. By advancing these priorities, we are protecting our homeland, creating jobs, and making sure the United States is never forced to rely on foreign adversaries to power our economy.

September is National Suicide Prevention Month, and it is an important reminder that help is always available. If you or someone you know is struggling, you can dial 988 to be connected with the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline. For our veterans, dialing 988 and then pressing 1 connects you directly with the Veterans Crisis Line, where trained responders stand ready to help. No one should face these challenges alone, so please reach out if you need support.

I voted this week to roll back three costly Biden administration energy rules that are driving up costs for working families and putting our energy security at risk. These measures will help reverse restrictions on American coal, oil, and gas production that have stifled jobs and pushed energy bills higher. By cutting Washington’s red tape and unleashing our own resources, we can restore American energy independence, lower costs, and strengthen our economy.

I voted in favor of the Stop Chinese Fentanyl Act this week to hold Chinese producers and officials accountable for the spread of illicit fentanyl. This legislation strengthens sanctions on those responsible and helps protect communities across Southern Illinois and our great nation from the deadly impact of synthetic opioids. We must continue to support our police officers in any way we can and restore law and order across our country.

This morning, I sat down with Secretary of the Air Force Troy Meink to talk about the future of Scott Air Force Base. SAFB is under consideration to receive the new KC-46 refueling aircraft, and I made sure to reinforce that there would be no better home than the 126th Air Refueling Wing. I’ll continue to do all I can to ensureSAFB's airmen and women have the resources, tools, and support to achieve their mission.

Today we remember V-J Day, the day Japan officially surrendered and World War II came to an end. It was a turning point in history and a victory made possible by the incredible sacrifice of the Greatest Generation. We owe so much to the men and women who served our nation during that time, and it is because of their courage that we are able to enjoy the freedoms we have today.

I was proud to help celebrate the ribbon cutting of the new VA Primary Care Clinic at Scott Air Force Base. This clinic will make it easier for our veterans to get the care they need close to home, and I’m grateful for the team working to make sure those who served our country are taken care of.

As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I had the opportunity to meet with Robert Etter and Matt Schwarz from the Illinois-Missouri chapter of Folds of Honor to talk about the incredible work they do for the families of our fallen and disabled service members, as well as first responders. Since 2007, Folds of Honor has provided scholarships that give spouses and children the chance to pursue their education, helping lift up families during difficult times. Their mission is a powerful reminder that the sacrifices of those who serve our country and communities are never forgotten, and it was inspiring to hear firsthand how they’re making a real difference in people’s lives.

I joined Rich Carter and David Curtin of the Technology and Manufacturing Association for a webinar to mark TMA’s 100th anniversary and talk about the future of small and midsize manufacturers in Illinois. With nearly 900 members and over 39,000 employees represented, TMA plays a vital role in keeping our economy strong. We discussed how the One Big Beautiful Bill protects 9,000 local manufacturing jobs, prevents a major tax hike, boosts investment in new facilities, and repeals costly Green New Deal mandates. I will always stand with our manufacturers and fight to keep good-paying jobs here in Illinois.

In Marion today I met with Southern Illinois Veterans Airport Director Doug Kimmel, their Chairman Dr. Javier Muniz, 1st Vice-Chairman Randy Youngblood, Operations Supervisor Bay Morgan, and the Director of Southern Illinois Airport in Carbondale Alyssa Connell to discuss how the One Big, Beautiful Bill will support our local aviation. With $12.5 billion dedicated to modernizing air traffic control technology, upgrading radar and telecom systems, and improving runway safety, this law gives our airports the resources they need to enhance safety and strengthen connectivity for Southern Illinois.

I kicked off the Farm Progress Show today by taking part in a tractor demo with Case IH and John Deere. We talked about the latest technology and innovations helping our farmers work smarter and keep our agriculture strong. https://t.co/I8HIyJY5gb

I joined Jim Wild, Executive Director of the East-West Gateway Council of Governments, to discuss the upcoming Transportation, Housing, and Urban Development funding bill and the importance of making that funding available to our local governments. As a member of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I’m focused on making sure local communities have a strong voice in how infrastructure dollars are spent so Southern Illinois families and businesses see real results.

Had a great discussion with Farm Bureau leaders from Richland, Wabash, and Edwards Counties about the issues most important to Southern Illinois agriculture. Over a good meal, we talked about how the One Big, Beautiful Bill delivers real wins for farmers – like stronger crop insurance, better disaster programs, and historic investments in market access and research. I also gave an update on the Farm Bill and some of my efforts to support rural roads, defend our farmland from foreign adversaries, and put farmers first. It’s always a privilege to hear directly from our farmers and producers that help feed and fuel Southern Illinois.
https://t.co/530meud1L8.

Big news for our rural communities today: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced the Trump administration will stop taxpayer dollars from going to solar farms – often owned by foreign adversaries – that take America’s prime farmland out of production. This has long been a big priority for me and why I introduced the SOLAR Act to stop incentivizing construction of large solar tracts on prime farmland. We shouldn’t be providing Green New Deal subsidies to weaken our agricultural communities and the production of the food and fuel we depend on. Great move by President Trump and Secretary Rollins!

I visited the Teffertiller Car Dealership in McLeansboro to talk with the owner, Alan Teffertiller and Hamilton County Board Chairman John Chapman about ways the One Big, Beautiful Bill will help Southern Illinoisans save on taxes when securing a loan for a new car. Thanks to this new law’s tax provisions, you can now deduct interest paid on a new car loan, helping working families keep more of their money.

Next up on my One Big, Beautiful Bill tour, I met with local families at a Working Families Roundtable at Southeastern Illinois University to talk about how this historic legislation strengthens households for the better. The law extends the Child Tax Credit to give families more support and creates new savings accounts for kids that get a government boost at birth and grow tax-free until they’re ready enter college or the workforce. It was great to hear directly from families about what matters most to them, and I’m proud to keep fighting for policies that help hardworking families in our region.

Excited to announce $300,000 in federal funding from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services for Lawrence County to boost overdose response efforts. This grant will help save lives and support local communities in fighting the opioid crisis.

No one has a pulse on their community better than a mayor. That’s why I’ve always prioritized being in touch with local leaders, as well as the constituents they serve, to best know how we can serve them in Washington. During my One Big, Beautiful Bill tour, I had the opportunities to visit with three mayors: David Woods of Palestine, Mikeal Shimer of Robinson, and Brandon Combs of Charleston. Thanks to each of you for all you do to strengthen the community you serve!

As a priority of my One Big, Beautiful Bill Tour, I joined Mayor Teresa Fielder in Oblong for a Main Street walk to visit some of the businesses that help this small community thrive. From the long-standing family service at Harmon’s Pharmacy to the craftsmanship at Village Stitchery, and the history preserved at Vault Antiques, each stop was a reminder of the heart and hard work that drive small towns in Southern Illinois.

Checked in with Crawford County Chairman Bill Burke, County Clerk Beckie Staley, and Resa Shaner of the Crawford County Development Association to discuss grant opportunities and how my office can keep working closely with them to continue developing our region. Always a pleasure to sit down with committed and hardworking local leaders.

I visited Sandy, a local homeowner in Effingham today to see firsthand how programs from Community Economic and Family Services help people with home repairs and improvements that make a real difference. After the tour, I joined a roundtable with CEFS leaders who support families across Clay and Effingham counties by providing services like housing assistance, job training, and emergency support. We had a productive conversation about how these programs help people overcome challenges and build stronger, more stable communities in Southern Illinois.

As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’m proud to see the VA reach record-breaking results for our nation’s heroes. This fiscal year, the VA has already processed over 2.5 million disability benefits claims, the most in history. Under President Trump’s leadership, we have cut the backlog by more than 37%, opened 16 new health care clinics, expanded after-hours appointments, accelerated access to community care, and made commonsense reforms to ensure veterans get the benefits and care they have earned.

The simmering frustrations of people in my district have been validated with today’s results of an independent audit of postal operations in St. Louis. Earlier this year, I appealed to the U.S. Postal Service for an audit of the St. Louis postal processing center because Southern Illinoisans have faced service failures, late utility bills, missed medications, and lost family documents for far too long. I’m thankful the Trump administration conducted the audit, identified the problems, and demanded accountability. It is past time to fix these staffing shortages, hold supervisors accountable, and get the machines in top working order.

Started off my One Big, Beautiful Bill Tour in Jonesboro with Mayor Asa Busby, Sheriff David Wilkins, and State Rep. Paul Jacobs visiting local shops like Country Roads Flowers & Gifts and talking with small business owners about what the new law means for them. We've expanded small business tax deductions, giving job creators the breathing room they need to grow and hire. As a former small business owner myself, it’s wonderful seeing the pride and determination of our local job creators.

Today I'm kicking off a tour across Southern Illinois highlighting the benefits of the “One Big, Beautiful Bill.” This landmark legislation, signed into law by President Trump on Independence Day, will help working families, small businesses, farmers, and local communities across the district. Stay tuned for updates from the road!

I was honored to be invited by President Trump to join him at the White House as he signed the VA Home Loan Program Reform Act into law. As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’ve worked closely with the President to deliver a partial VA claims program helping veterans keep their homes when they struggle with their mortgage. It replaces a Biden-era program that wasted billions in taxpayer dollars and put the entire VA home loan system at risk. Thank you, President Trump!

My staff will be hosting mobile office hours across Southern Illinois this August so you can speak with our casework experts face-to-face with comfort and convenience. Please visit with any questions you may have regarding veterans’ benefits, Social Security, Medicare, the IRS, and more.

I visited the Anheuser-Busch facility in St. Louis this afternoon and met with some of the 200 hundred Southern Illinoisans employed there. I was given an up close look at the production process and discussed the company’s workforce programs and community partnerships, especially their work employing veterans. A great American company investing in local communities and helping create good jobs that strengthen the economy.

Back in March, I urged the Department of Energy to oppose the Grain Belt Express, a massive $4.9 billion, taxpayer-funded, Biden-era project that would have laid one of the largest transmission lines through the heart of our Eastern Illinois counties. Local farmers were rightly concerned they would lose their land to the government through eminent domain. I'm pleased to report DOE has confirmed with my office it will not move forward with the loan guarantee. This is a big win for property rights in the rural region.

It was great to meet with the women of American Trucking Associations’ Women in Motion Council. These drivers are breaking barriers in the trucking industry, and their stories make clear just how urgent a need it is to fix the national shortage of safe truck parking. We had a valuable conversation about my Truck Parking Safety Improvement Act and the need to keep pushing for solutions that protect all drivers and keep our supply chain moving.

Happy to announce today that the Department of Veterans Affairs will fund an additional $800 million in infrastructure upgrades this year, including improvements to the Marion VA Medical Center and the John Cochran and Jefferson Barracks facilities in St. Louis. Southern Illinois veterans deserve the highest standard of support and these upgrades can make a life-changing difference for veterans in need of cutting-edge care. As Chairman of the House Veteran Affairs’ Committee, I’ll continue working closely with the Trump administration to get our local VA facilities the resources they need to serve those who served our country.

Today I reintroduced the Upending Secret Postal Shutdowns (USPS) Act to bring transparency and accountability for sudden post office closures. Rural communities, in particular, are often left in the dark when a local post office is “temporarily” shut down, with no timeline or communication for reopening. This bill sets clear timelines for public notification and restores trust by making sure people know when and how their service will return.

Many Southern Illinoisans will recognize the name Ray Doerr, who passed away earlier this month at the blessed age of 98. Ray was the one of the first people who encouraged me to get involved in public service, and I will always be grateful for his mentorship and counsel. His decades of leadership, tireless work ethic, and deep love for his community left a lasting impact in Jackson County and beyond. My heartfelt condolences go out to his son, Jeff, and the entire Doerr family.

For farmers in Southern Illinois, the rural roads used to haul grain for weighing or to transport feed and fertilizer are often narrow, weight-limited, and in disrepair. These first-mile and last-mile connections are just as important as the highways they lead to. That’s why today I proudly introduced the Agricultural and Rural Road Improvement Program Act which puts real investment into the roads and bridges that get crops from the field to market safely and efficiently.

These hostile regimes are not just buying property; they are positioning themselves to undermine our economy and control key parts of our food system. This week I proudly voted for this year’s defense appropriations bill to give our troops the tools, training, and pay raise they deserve. In a big win for national security and our dedicated servicemembers at Scott Air Force Base, this bill strengthens our military readiness, counters threats from China and Iran, and blocks Biden’s woke Pentagon policies. It also boosts investment in American-made weapons systems and secures our southern border by banning taxpayer funds from being used to house illegal immigrants on U.S. military bases. I’ll always put our national defense and America’s security first.

Veterans can press 1 to be connected directly with professionals at the Veterans Crisis Line, many of whom are veterans themselves. If you need help, don’t wait.

President Trump has made clear that all freedom loving nations have a responsibility to shoulder the load for protecting our values in a dangerous world. For far too long, the United States carried a disproportionate financial weight at NATO, while allies failed to pay their fair share. But that changed yesterday. Thanks to President Trump’s bold leadership, NATO countries almost universally have committed to increasing their defense spending to 5% of GDP by 2035. This is a major victory for American taxpayers and a safer world.

As Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’m proud to have helped pass this year’s funding bill for veterans and military construction. It FULLY funds veterans’ health care, benefits, mental health programs, and backs President Trump’s effort to end veteran homelessness. I’m especially proud of the provision I fought for to protect the Second Amendment rights of our veterans by blocking the VA from sending a veteran’s name to the NICS list without a judge’s ruling.
